snippet: A letter arrived at a woman’s Harlem townhouse in 2011, from a former prisoner claiming to own the building. The woman shrugged it off, but the letters kept coming.
abstract: Michael Wilson Crime Scene column describes unsettling dispute between former convict Patrick Barclay and current owners of townhouse he once owned on Fifth Ave in Harlem; notes Barclay claims house still belongs to him, and has stumbled into legal trouble by listing it as his home address; convicted sex offenders must list register lawful home address with New York State Sex Offender Registry, but Barclay has broken law by listing Harlem townhouse as his address.
lead_paragraph: A letter arrived at a woman’s Harlem townhouse in 2011, from a former prisoner claiming to own the building. The woman shrugged it off, but the letters kept coming.

headline.print_headline: A Series of Unsettling Letters, and an Ex-Prisoner Too Close to Home
headline.main: A Heap of Unwanted Mail, From an Ex-Prisoner Too Close to Home
